unnormalised: What are some effective waste management strategies being implemented in India to tackle the growing problem of pollution?
normalised: What are some effective waste management strategies being implemented in India to tackle the growing problem of pollution?

unnormalised: The issue of waste management in India is a multifaceted challenge with significant environmental and public health implications. As of 2023, India generates an estimated 62 million tonnes of waste annually, a figure projected to increase substantially.
normalised: The issue of waste management in India is a multifaceted challenge with significant environmental and public health implications. As of two thousand and twenty three, India generates an estimated sixty two million tonnes of waste annually, a figure projected to increase substantially.

unnormalised: Several strategies are being implemented, though their effectiveness varies. The Swachh Bharat Mission, launched on 02/10/2014, aims to improve cleanliness and sanitation across the country, including waste management. This includes promoting source segregation – separating dry and wet waste at the household level. Many cities like Indore have seen relative success using this model.
normalised: Several strategies are being implemented, though their effectiveness varies. The S W A C H H Bharat Mission, launched on second October two thousand and fourteen, aims to improve cleanliness and sanitation across the country, including waste management. This includes promoting source segregation – separating dry and wet waste at the household level. Many cities like Indore have seen relative success using this model.

unnormalised: Furthermore, composting and biogas plants are being encouraged to process organic waste. Municipal corporations in cities like Mumbai are experimenting with waste-to-energy plants, although the environmental viability of some remains debated. The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) has also issued guidelines for the management of plastic waste, pushing for increased recycling and extended producer responsibility (EPR).

unnormalised: One innovative approach is the use of Decentralized Waste Management Systems, seen in some smaller towns and even within communities in larger cities. This involves processing waste locally, reducing the burden on centralised facilities and transportation costs (which can be quite high, say Rs. 5000 per truckload for 10 km in certain regions).

unnormalised: However, significant challenges remain. Open dumping and burning of waste are still prevalent practices, contributing to air and water pollution. Illegal dumping sites are a common sight along the Yamuna River and in many peri-urban areas. Enforcement of regulations remains weak in many states. It's a race against time, and improvements are necessary before 17:00 hrs on 15/08/2047, our 100th Independence Day! Further research and investment, starting from 09:00 hrs tomorrow, are critical for a sustainable future.
